item.title: Neighbor Island Power -- for Sale to Oahu?
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
If you asked the public if they favor reducing the Hawaii's dependence on imported oil, you'd likely find strong support and unity to do so. But how we get to the goal is another matter.

A group called "Friends of Lanai" is objecting to a plan to construct approximately 170 wind turbines on their island with an installed generation capacity of 200 megawatts. Almost all of that power would be exported to Oahu using undersea cables. You can read about the group's views here: http://bit.ly/dQsXxh

What do you think? Should the Friends' views on preserving their island from this Big Wind development prevail, or does Oahu have a good case for using energy in the wind that's harvested on the neighbor islands?

item.title: A new way to calculate electric bills
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
The electric utilities in Hawaii and Maui counties began calculating their customers' electric bills a new way in January. According to the Star-Advertiser < http://bit.ly/g2PK8K >, a tiered-rate system is being implemented that rewards customers who use less electricity by charging them less per kilowatthour that heavier users. The Public Utilities Commission approved the tiered rates to encourage conservation. Hawaiian Electric Company has yet to announce when the new rates will be implemented on Oahu.

Read the link to the newspaper story (above) and let us know what you think of the new system.

item.title: Big Changes Proposed for Hawaiian Electric Industries
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
A new company has been formed with the stated intention to raise private investor capital and purchase Hawaiian Electric Industries from HEI's current shareholders. See http://kuokoa.com/

According to Kuokoa Inc.'s officers, their goal is to speed the transition from fossil fuel power generation to renewable technologies and end HEI's utility companies' reliance on fossil fuel within 10 years. They've said they believe HEI is moving too slowly in transitioning to green energy technologies on Oahu, Maui, Molokai, Lanai and the Big Island and that by taking HEI private, they can move more quickly. The company also proposes to eventually buy the Kauai utility and establish a statewide electric rate of 20 cents per kilowatthour, less than what residential customers are paying now.

Kuokoa's announcement has generated considerable media coverage that likely will continue. What's your opinion?

item.title: Biofuel in Hawaii
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Hawaiian Electric Company has signed a contract with a Big Island company that will provide biofuel that's grown and processed on that island for use by the island's utility to create electricity. HECO describes the contract's provisions in a press release: http://bit.ly/g2XYkK

The contract anticipates that the cost of the biofuel-generated electricity in the early years, at least, will exceed the price of the fossil fuel generation it offsets. The contract proposes to spread those increased costs among all HECO customers on all the islands it serves -- Oahu, Maui, Molokai, Lanai and Hawaii. The company's press release says that based on December 2010 fuel costs, the added cost to customers would be less than 1/3 of a cent per kilowatthour, or $1.55 to $1.86 per month for a typical residential customer bill.

The Public Utilities Commission will have the final say on this proposal, which appears to be a "first" in Hawaii as a way to encourage renewable energy production without unduly burdening customers of any one island.

What do you think about this proposal? Do you support it because of its stated purpose? Do you oppose it? Let us know your views.

item.title: About EVs
item.dc:creator: Kelli Miura
item.content:encoded:
Whether it's the Nissan Leaf, Tesla or Chevy Volt, electric vehicles (EVs) are of growing popularity and interest to all interested in creating a more sustainable future. Benefits include:

says
Lower Cost
EVs generally cost less in total to own, operate and maintain than combustion-powered vehicles, even in cases where the initial purchase price is somewhat higher.

More Reliability
Electric motors have very few moving parts and donâ??t need fluids such as engine oil, anti-freeze or transmission fluid, so they require relatively little maintenance and are far less likely to leak. Excellent reliability means down time is less likely, too.

No pollutant Emissions
EVs emit no pollutant from the tailpipe, so theyâ??re cleaner for the environment and better for everyoneâ??s respiratory health.

Quieter
EVs also run far more quietly than their combustion-powered counterparts which enhances worker health and comfort â?? a smart move in an era of rising medical costs.

Lower Overall Emissions
The overall emissions associated with using EVs are typically far less than the emissions from their combustion-powered counterparts.

Overnight Charging
Most EVs charge up at night when system wide demand for electricity is low. They tap existing generating capacity that is not fully used rather than increasing demand for new capacity.

Reduced Oil Consumption
Choosing EVs instead of combustion powered vehicles contributes to reduced dumping of engine oils into the environment and reduced U.S reliance on foreign oil.

Credit: San Diego Gas & Electric

item.title: HECO Starts Tiered Rate Plan
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Hawaiian Electric Company has implemented a new three-tier rate plan that has higher costs for customers who use the most electricity < http://bit.ly/fpEFF1 >. The intent is to provide an incentive for customers to use less electricity. What's your reaction to the new plan? Will you consciously check your kilowatthour (KWH) use in your most recent or future bill? If you decide to conserve, where will you try to economize in your home, office or business? The inquiring minds here at Hawaii Energy want to know!

MARCH 3 UPDATE: The Star-Advertiser has a story today clarifying the new rate structure under the headline [color="#FFA500"][color="#FF0000"]"Electricity-price tiers will not increase costs"[/color][/color] < http://bit.ly/gOxL1H >. It covers the same information that's in our IMPORTANT DETAIL post immediately below -- but with more detail.

IMPORTANT DETAIL: I just confirmed this with Hawaiian Electric Company. The typical household on Oahu uses 600 KWH per month. Using that number as an example, the lowest per-KWH rate will apply to the first 350 KWH, and the tier two rate would apply to the next 250. I.E., there's a stair-step approach to applying the rates. Someone who uses 1,250 KWH in a month would have the top tier's rate apply only to the last 50 KWH.

CHECK YOUR BILL: Our most recent electric bill for our four-bedroom, three and one-half-bath house was more than 700 KWH during the month. Suggest you check your latest bill, too. Does anybody have a bill showing more than 1200 KWH, which is where the higher rates kick in? If so, do you plan to cut back on your electricity use, and if so, how?

You have to consider the other fees included in your bill. the Customer Charge, Non-Fuel Energy and Base Fuel Energy all add to your bill then they apply the official rate. Kimo, thanks for posting. You ask an excellent question -- but the issue here is whether your electric bill will actually fall. The wind may be free, but the cost of the investment to capture that free fuel with turbines, substations, transmission lines, battery storage systems, roads, etc., is substantial. The question citizens/rate payers might well ask is, "Will all this new infrastructure increase my electric bill?" Somebody will have to pay for it, and that's nearly always the customer.

Renewable energy isn't free. Hawaii is intent on increasing renewable energy's contributuion to the grid, because in the long run, getting off oil will be a good bet, but there may be some "pain" involved in achieving that goal.

What's your reaction to that, Kimo?

item.title: President Urges Steep Cut in Oil Imports, Expanded Renewables
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
President Obama delivered what's being called a major speech on energy policy today (3/30) at Georgetown University in which he called for sharp reductions in oil imports and development of alternative fuels to replace imported petroleum. "Let's actually have a plan," he said. "Let's, yes, increase domestic oil production, but let's also invest in solar and wind and geothermal and biofuels, and let's make our buildings more efficient and our cars more efficient." http://usat.ly/hViPdd

Hawaii's geothermal resource already is touted by some as Hawaii's fuel of the future -- a source for electrical energy (it already is providing 30 megawatts of power on the Big Island) and other fuels that could be created by tapping into the geothermal field. You can download the Geothermal Working Group Interim Report at the Ku`oko`a website: http://bit.ly/hcALRm

What's your reaction to the President's policy speech? What roles can Hawaii -- the nation's most oil-dependent state -- play in achieving greater energy independence? Is the state doing enough? Are we missing opportunities? What else needs doing?

Join the discussion here on the Forum simply by registering (at top right) and sharing your views with all of Hawaii.

item.title: New Twists in 'Big Wind' Energy Project
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Molokai Ranch has turned aside First Wind, the energy company that's built wind farms on Molokai and Oahu, for the Big Wind project's farm on the Friendly Isle. The ranch wants Pattern Energy of San Francisco to build up to 200 megawatts of installed capacity on the island, but some Molokai residents are opposed to the plan.

First Wind wants the Public Utilities Commission to extend the company's deadline to find a site for its proposed farm, but Hawaiian Electric Company is objecting -- http://bit.ly/hqoVhu Some are even suggesting that if no Molokai site can be found, all 400 megawatts of wind could be built on Lanai, which in turn is alarming to a group called Friends of Lanai.

What's going on? And what do you think about it? If you haven't registered to join the discussion here at the Forum, click on the link at the upper right and let us know your views on Big Wind.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Another twist.. now the state is potentially talking about using eminent domain to get the land for Big Wind. see the PBN article.

And in yet another twist, Castle & Cooke has "allocated" 200 megawatts of wind energy that it theoretically could build on Lanai to Molokai: http://bit.ly/ewhhg1

Give us your feedback on the Big Wind project, which would develop wind farms on Lanai and Molokai and transmit the electrical energy to Oahu via undersea cable.

item.title: As Oil Price Increases, How Do You Save?
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
The price of Brent and West Texas Intermediate crude oil is above $125 and $110 per barrel respectively, and that's driving up the cost of electricity, gasoline, food and other necessities correspondingly.

What are you doing to conserve -- or are you? Nationally, people are buying less gas for their cars < http://bit.ly/hHSjAg >. Are you cutting back? What about electricity for the home and business? Have you adopted a new awareness about "phantom loads" of TV sets and other appliances? Are you installing a PV system to drastically slash your electric bill?

Hawaii Energy's Forum wants to know your experience and outlook about Hawaii's energy issues. We never learn less from our life experiences, and we want to learn from you. Just register by clicking the link in the top-right corner and become a regular visitor and contributor to the dialogue about energy in Hawaii -- just about the most important one going.

item.title: Hawaii Electric Bills Near All-Time High
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Your monthly electric bill is another good assessment of Hawaii's near-total dependence on imported oil -- along with what you're paying at the pump to fill up your car. According to the latest information from Hawaiian Electric, Oahu residential customers are paying nearly 29 cents per kilowatthour (KWH), Maui residents 34 cents, Big Islanders 38 cents and our friends on Kauai nearly 43 cents/KWH! http://bit.ly/gTUIOI

Hawaii leads the nation in both gasoline prices and KWH costs. What are you doing to lessen the impact of high-priced oil on you and your family. Hawaii Energy's Forum is where to let loose with your ideas and reactions. Just please keep it civil. Mahalo.

item.title: Join the "BIG WIND" Discussion
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Perhaps the largest renewable energy project ever proposed for Hawaii -- Big Wind -- has received considerable media attention in recent weeks due to its complexity, controversy and its fluid mix of corporate participants. With a presumed cost of $3 billion for two 200-megawatt wind farms originally planned for Molokai and Lanai and an undersea cable to connect them to Oahu, Big Wind represents a huge investment that ultimately would be paid for by electricity customers.

Hawaii Energy wants to foster greater discussion of the Big Wind proposal here on the Forum. The Forum is new this year, and we hope it can become the "go-to" place on the 'net to exchange ideas and comments among Hawaii residents on energy-related issues. Big Wind is the big issue right now, so we want your input. If you haven't registered already, click on the link in the upper-right corner; participation is free and easy, and registering takes only a minute.

For background, enter "big wind project" in a search engine window. I've written several posts in March/April 2011 on Big Wind at an energy blog: http://bit.ly/cYOfJ0 The posts have links to numerous news articles on the project. Let us know what you think of Big Wind, the process followed so far to create it, the views of residents on Molokai and Lanai and anything else you feel needs to be discussed. This is YOUR Forum.

4/28 UPDATE: The Friends of Lanai group has asked the Public Utilities Commission to throw out all current plans for Big Wind and start the bidding all over again to build the energy facilities: http://bit.ly/jx1YMP

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Who came up with the $3 billion total cost of Big Wind?
The $3 billion price is the estimate most participants agree the project would cost. They include the State, Hawaiian Electric and the wind and cable developers.

If this holds true, this would not bode well for economic feasibility, with 3000 M$/(2x200MW) = 7.5 $/W, compard to individual wind turbine installation costs of ~2 $/W. Of course this includes the cable â?? but I wonder what the wind-farms alone would cost for this project, so that "cable" energy transfer cost can be compared with "fuel generation" and transfer cost

The Public Utilities Commission has rejected First Wind's request for an extension of the deadline for the company to secure a land deal to build al portion of the Big Wind project: http://bit.ly/mgUtkz
More on Big Wind from the June 12th Star-Advertiser: http://bit.ly/lxFGs8

item.title: Algae-to-Oil
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Every new development in renewable energy development has the potential to help Hawaii get off imported petroleum, so the announcement that a company is producing oil from algae on the Big Island supports the trend. Cellena Inc. says it will begin commercial production in 2014 of its crop, which could be directed for a variety of uses, from biodiesel fuels for automobiles and power plants to cosmetics and industrial chemicals, according to a Honolulu Star-Advertiser story: http://bit.ly/kFGJsg

That being the case, what do you think the best use of algae-produced oil is in Hawaii? Should fuel for cars and power plants have a higher priority in light of Hawaii's severe fossil-fuel dependence? Share your view with all of Hawaii here at the Forum.

item.title: Proposal: Condemn Molokai land for Big Wind project
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Columnist Jay Fidell has a proposal in today's Honolulu Star-Advertiser < http://bit.ly/iqo6U7 > that could stir up some controversy and kick-start a discussion on the Big Wind energy project here at the Forum. Fidell encourages Governor Abercrombie to seize land on Molokai under eminent domain powers and thereby fast-track the plan to build a 200 megawatt wind farm on the island for the benefit of Oahu consumers. This Topic's moderator already has posted his views at his energy blog: http://bit.ly/jsmnUT Do you agree or disagree with the views expressed there and/or by Fidell?

Hawaii Energy's Forum is the place to start the discussion. Please weigh in.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Mr. Fidell's article is truly amazing. Have we learned nothing from our State's history? Would we now condemn land on an island with an over 50% Native Hawaiian population so that a few get very, very rich -- all for perhaps 10% of O'ahu's electrical needs? Are we blind to our own history?

Mr. Murdock (and remember, this Mainland developer owns Castle & Cooke privately) stands to earn - based on his recent agreement with HECO-- about $111,000,000 each year. Then add to that the enormous gifts we taxpayers give him -- 65% of his investment comes back to him in tax credits, tax-based grants and loans. And so, in exchange for the irrevocable alteration of 1/4 of this island, he offers as a "community benefit" to Lana'i an annual contribution of 1% of his revenue. With Lana'i's 3,100 residents, that equals a HUGE donation of $340/resident each year. Keep in mind that for some Lana'i residents, that is their MONTHLY electric bill.

Pono? I think not. Say NO to Big Wind.

Wow!

Jay Fidel says that Big Wind = statewide grid. This is simply not the case. Condemning Molokai would be a complete nightmare and probably set us back decades when the backlash hits. Why not get the smart grid installed on each island now instead of waiting for the connections to the other islands. We could probably save 10 to 20% of our electrical usage by adding the ability to monitor our grid in real time and make changes that are more important and lower cost.

Without smart-grids in each island, how can we expect to leverage a state-wide system?

-rc

item.title: Hydro Power a Hot Topic on Kauai
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson

Some are describing it as a "turf war" -- the struggle between two companies to develop hydro-electric power on Kauai. One of them -- Free Flow Power -- is working as a "development agent" for the Kauai Island Utility Cooperative, and its project seemingly is a competitor with Pacific Light & Power, a Kauai-based company, to develop hydro power from the same water resource. item.title: The Blue Revolution
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Pat Takahashi is among the few in Hawaii who have been invested for decades in the quest for long-term solutions to the state's energy crisis. He coined (and copyrighted) the phrase The Blue Revolution as the overall concept to develop ocean-based technologies that could provide abundant energy, fresh water and other products from the world's largest solar energy "battery" -- the tropical ocean that surrounds Hawaii.

We recommend reading and following Dr. Takahashi's many posts at his website(s) and other locations, such as Huffington Post. They are thought-provoking, and if Hawaii needs anything in a decade likely to accentuate our dependence on external sources of energy, it's all the thinking we can muster. Here's Dr. Takahashi's Blue Revolution Hawaii site: http://bluerevolutionhawaii.blogspot.com

item.title: The Feed-In Tarriff -- Is It Working?

item.content:encoded: The Public Utilities Commission approved the feed-in-tariff program to allow independent energy producers to sell power to Hawaiian Electric Company at a fixed price for 20 years, but a recent report says less than a handful of producers have taken advantage of the program. item.title: With Gas Prices Down, Is Your Driving Up?
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Gas prices are falling like a rock (for now) in Hawaii; the statewide average price for a gallon of regular as this is written is $4.107, down nearly 12 cents from a week ago and nearly half al dollar from the all-time high of $4.594 set on May 6. What a relief, right? But we're paying more than $4/gallon, and there's no telling with any certainty whether the price will continue to fall or turn around on a dime and head up again.

What happens to your driving habits with gas price fluctuations? Do you cut back during the peak periods, maybe take public transit?

More importantly, how does it feel to be a complete and total victim of the powers that determine how much we pay for energy?

item.title: It's "Energy Challenge" Month in Hawaii
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson

item.title: Hawaii Leaves ("Nissan Leaf"s)
item.dc:creator: Russell Castagnaro
item.content:encoded:
Word on the street is that nearly 100 Nissan Leaf vehicles were delivered to Hawaii in July. That means a bunch of us are out there driving these new vehicles around. Feel free to use this as a place to share information about your Leaf and where prospective buyers can come to find out more about the whole purchasing process.

I took delivery of my Leaf this Saturday, July 30th. It was probably the nicest auto purchasing experience I've ever had. Yes, I know the wait was loooooonnnnngggg, but really it wasn't that big of a deal. My house is powered by PV via net metering, so I feel pretty good about the whole thing. On Sunday I even considered driving by the Costco Fueling station and honking wildly... Good taste won the day however.

I opted for the 39 month lease with $2,000 down. I normally don't like leases, but the difference was really negligible. The lease insulates me from risk if newer technology makes the 2nd generation electric cars significantly better or if there are major problems with the battery and allows me to keep the car if I really want to.

The Process:

Signing up for the waiting list is quite simple. The web site is http://www.nissanusa.com/leaf-electric-car/login/auth and it works pretty well. Once you are signed up (They are sold out of the 2011 models) you come to a fun menu which I have provided as a picture [attachment=8:Screen shot 2011-08-01 at 10.15.07 PM.png]

The steps are:
1) Sign up
2) Pay your reservation fee and choose your dealership.
3) Order your home assessment - You pay a fee here and they send someone who Nissan contracts from AeroVironment who contracts with them.. The short story is that the price they give you is relatively crazy unless there is nothing to do but plug it in. My garage is pretty far from my electrical panel, so for the same price they gave me to install the charger, I was able to rewire half of my house. Now I have an electric car, PV panels and no more knob and tube wiring left in the house!!
4) Order Your Leaf! The fun begins.
5) Schedule the installation of your charging dock. If you go your own route, you have to buy the charger. I'll post on options later.
6) Optional - Set up your carwings account. This is how Big Brother Nissan will help you do everything from finding charges, to navigating, to tieing your shoes. I hate to say it, but I really like it. I forgot to do this before I got my car. If you feel uncomfortable (no not you folks on foursquare, facebook and google+, everyone else) you don't have to do it.
7) Arrange Finaning - Either purchase or lease, trade in or sell your car. The only surprise here was that the lease was so reasonable.
8) Schedule your pickup with your dealer rep.

I purchased through King Windward Nissan even though New City is in town. I once tried unsuccessfully to get a replacement key for my Nissan Versa at New City. After 4 hours and 2 trips, I never got the key. King got it for me in one short trip. They also got my Leaf order as a result. I worked with [email="lkalua@kingwindward.com"]Lahela Kalua[/email] there and she was awesome. There was some confusion in financing when I filled out my paperwork. Nothing they said made sense, but I really needed to go pick up the babysitter so I signed. Before I left, I mentioned to Lahela that the payment didn't quite sync with the quote she gave me after I signed the lease docs.

She researched it and had the financing folks reduce my payment by $9! Not a big difference, but less than the quote she gave me. That is $350 she saved me. My kids loved the briefing she gave us too.

I didn't even mention the best thing. This car is SOOOOOO great. For some reason I assumed this would be a trim level equivalent to a Nissan Versa or lower range vehicle. I was wrong. The interior is more like a Z or Maxima. Really slick and readable. The onboard computer system rocks. The shifter, power and parking brake make me feel like I am at the helm of the Enterprise and there is a heck of a lot of room in the car.

I drove the car about 65 miles on the first day (Aina Hina and back 4 times) and there was still plenty of juice in the battery. I plugged in the trickle charger (110v) and it was charged up by noon the next day when I checked it.

This is a great car!

item.title: Aina Koa Pono biofuel hearing
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
The Public Utilities Commission hearing in Hilo yesterday produced competing testimony on the proposed Aina Koa Pono biodiesel plant and the plan to share its costs among electricity customers on Hawaii, Oahu, Molokai, Lanai and Maui. (See the story in West Hawaii Today: http://bit.ly/ptty2g ) Some supporters said the construction and operations jobs are badly needed on the Big Island; others are focused on reducing the state's dependence on imported fossil fuels.

But opponents say they're concerned about the costs involved in bringing Aina Koa Pono's fuel into the generation mix and how those costs would be covered by increases in electricity rates. One proposal is to share the increased costs of this energy source (renewable energy hardly ever reduces expenses) among all customers of Oahu-based Hawaiian Electric Company and its subsidiaries in Maui and Hawaii counties. Doing so would increase a 500-kwh monthly bill $1.75, according to advocates, but if all costs were born by Big Island customers of Hawaii Electric Light Company, the bill hike would be about $10 per month.

We're interested in knowing what you think of this proposal. If you haven't registered for your no-cost participation, please do so by clicking the link in the upper right-hand corner, complete the process and then start writing. If you live anywhere in the state besides Kauai, you'll be helping pay for the Aina Koa Pono operation. Tell us your thoughts.

OTI has been pursuing a contract with Hawaiian Electric Company for years, and with this latest milestone passed, a power purchase agreement might be in the offiing. OTI has had a 100-MW plant "grandfathered" in HECO's long-term power planning for years.

item.title: Yes to Biofuels, but Use it Where?
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Pacific Business News speculates this week < http://bit.ly/osUOLK > on what a new biofuels initiative announced by the White House < http://1.usa.gov/rtteVt > could mean to Hawaii, going so far as to hint that it could mean a lot if the entire half-billion-dollar commitment were destined for this state. That's highly unlikely, even with Senator Inouye on the job, so maybe a better question is what the effort could mean to the airlines that bring tourists to our state. Tourists are the life blood of our economy, and if escalating oil prices push millions of them out of the long-haul flight market, we're sunk.

President Obama's focus during his bus tour was on rural America, but if he and his advisers want to prioritize the needs based on the disaster $200/barrel oil would present to all the states, the President's home state would have to be at the top. We're more dependent on oil to power our economy, from electricity to transportation fuels, than anywhere else.

Here's a proposition just waiting for your comments: The vast majority of new biofuel production should be designated exclusively for transportation uses, with a major chunk of that going into aircraft fuel. The day tourists decide a 5-plus hour flight to Hawaii is just too expensive is the day we become less than viable as a place to live, work and play. Some might like that, but as a concept for sustainability in Hawaii, it won't fly.

Add your comments here by signing up in the upper right (for free) and start sharing your views here at The Forum.

item.title: Vermont Has Big Wind Concerns
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Turns out the size and location of the turbines planned for "utility-sized" wind farms in Vermont are creating some push-back, from New England to the Pacific. Vermont residents gathered today to rally against 400-foot-plus turbines on ridges and mountains. Their concerns seem to mirror what Molokai and Lanai residents are saying about the proposed Big wind project here.

The Hawaii Energy Options blog has links to Vermont-based resources: http://bit.ly/r1mzCx Do you identify with Vermonters' concerns? Let us know your reaction by joining the discussion here at the Forum.

item.title: Part Official Backs 'Big Wind'
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
(Make that PARTY official in the headline; can't figure out how to edit it!)

Hello, Maui. The Big Wind renewable energy project continues to swirl around your island and the entire county. Here's the latest from one of your community's leaders as he supports the Governor's energy plan, including the 400-MW project slated for two of Maui County's islands: http://bit.ly/pLAxxT Back to you for your view. Just sign up and start writing.

item.title: Molokai Residents Speak Up on Big Wind
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
"Molokai says 'no' to a lot of things, but we do this to perpetuate our land, our culture and our lifestyle."

That's just one quote from a new video produced by the I Aloha Molokai group that makes clear at least its members' resistance to the Big Wind energy project on their island. Here's another:

"These developers don't care about Molokai. They just want to make their profits and move on to the next money-making location."

The video's professional quality speaks volumes about how opponents want to get their message across to the rest of the state, not just what they believe about the proposed project that would place 200 megawatts (or more) of wind energy turbine generators on the island. Civil Beat has a link to this video: http://bit.ly/ogRskI

Watch it, reflect on it and then tell us what you think about the I Aloha Molokai message. Mahalo.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: This video has some pretty compelling arguments against Big Wind. Some not so big ones too. I noticed civil beat comments have started...

item.title: Cloudy Day? Study Says No Problem
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
This has to be good news to the Hawaii solar industry and everybody who thinks solar energy can contribute more to the grid than some might have assumed.

The Star-Advertiser has a story today reporting on a new study's conclusions about the effects of clouds on PV panels' ability to capture solar energy: http://bit.ly/o4p2qP

Does this finding change your plans about installing solar energy PVs on your roof? Let us know what's holding you back -- if anything.

item.title: PUC Sets Reliability Docket
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
One of the ongoing complaints of solar energy advocates is that concerns about the reliability of Hawaiian Electric's grids is slowing adoption of PV systems in the islands. The Hawaii Public Utilities Commission has heard enough about this issue to conclude that it deserves its own docket to investigate the implementation of reliability standards.

Read about it here in Pacific Business News -- http://bit.ly/opjLws -- and tell us what you think about the speed or slowness of renewable energy integration into the grids.

item.title: "Huge" PV Plant Planned in Ewa
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Solar energy projects are leaping ahead in size, and what seemed large a couple years ago seems tiny when compared to what could be next. The Hawaii Community Development Authority is talking about an $80 million 20-megawatt plant on land once occupied by the Barbers Point Naval Air Station.

PBN had the story today: http://bit.ly/pbgTvR

item.title: "Oil is everything in Hawaii"
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Former CIA Director James Woolsey called attention to Hawaii's overwhelming dependence on oil as he spoke to a gathering last evening on the 10th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks. Woolsey is in town to attend and speak at the Asia Pacific Clean Energy Summit. He's a board member of Ku`oko`a, which has announced its intention to acquire Hawaiian Electric Industries, take it private and develop renewable energy in the state faster than the current pace.

"Oil is everything in Hawaii," Woolsey said. "This is the place to start. Hawaii could be the place where OPEC's monopoly can meet its match."

You can read more at the greentechmedia website: http://bit.ly/qrkxQE

item.title: Is it NIMBYism or Something Else?
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Star-Advertiser columnist Jay Fidell has a commentary today suggesting that NIMBYism is at the heart of the opposition to Big Wind on Lanai and Molokai. Here's the link: http://bit.ly/pgXCGd

What do you think? Should all renewable energy projects go through without opposition because they would help reduce the state's dependence on imported energy? Or are there local values that must come into play, such as reverence for the land, culture and tradition?

Read up on the issue and let us know what you think -- here at the Forum.

item.title: HECO strikes deal for biofuel
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
This one pits opposing viewpoints -- that biofuel is just fine for power plant use vs. the view that biofuels should be reserved for transportation fuel.

The Star-Advertiser has the story today of the deal between an enterprise on Kauai to deliver biofuel to the Kahe power plant starting a few years from now; here's the story's link: http://bit.ly/rfxczM

What's your view on this issue -- biofuel for plants or biofuel for planes, as an example?

An interesting side note: The story says HECO did not disclose details of the contract. That means electricity consumers don't know what the price per-kilowatthour will be for electricity generated by burning biofuel. How does that sit with you? Register in the upper-right corner and start commenting right here, for all Hawaii to read.

item.title: James Woolsey Urges Energy Action
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
The Third Annual Asia Pacific Energy Summit and Expo has attracted some big names and faces recognizable from the cable networks talking head galleries. One of them is former CIA Director James Woolsey, who's been recruited to the board of directors of Ku`oko`a, the Hawaii start-up that wants to buy out Hawaiian Electric Industries and take it private.

Civil Beat caught up with Mr. Woolsey at the Summit and sat down with him for an extended interview, which was videotaped. You can read about it and watch it at Civil Beat's website: http://bit.ly/ov46Xm

The Summit and Mr. Woolsey's remarks aren't happening in a vacuum, of course. Big Wind is still being pushed as a key component of the Abercrombie Administration's clean-energy program, but residents of Lanai and Molokai are fighting the plan to install dozens of "industrial scale" wind turbines on their land.

What's your take of this issue -- the need for speed vs opposition to large impacts that are expected to be associated with Big Wind?

This Forum exists to share viewpoints on energy-related issues, including this one, so if you haven't registered, please do so by following the links in the upper right corner. Mahalo.

item.title: OTEC Corp to Build OTEC
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
For generations, ocean thermal energy conversion has been touted as the best long-term, big-scale renewable energy option for Hawaii. The hold-up has always been the cost to build the first small plants to prove the concept on a commercial scale. The money now appears to be available.

OTE Corporation has signed a memo of understanding with the utility that provides electricity in The Bahamas to build to 10-MW plants using its own financial resources and none from the utility and government. Two newspapers -- The Tribune < http://bit.ly/rlOBeD > and The Nassau Guardian < http://bit.ly/qeIh5D > have stories today.

Will this lead to an OTEC plant of ANY size being constructed here in Hawaii -- perhaps off the coast near the Kahe power plant on Oahu? One can wonder -- and one would hope that if OTE Corp can build plants in The Bahamas, they and/or can get the financing to build here in Hawaii. The energy temperature resource may be better in The Bahamas than Hawaii (that's what the utility says), but it's not all that bad here. Let's get going.

For more background on OTEC, visit the Hawaii Energy Options blog: http://hawaiienergyoptions.blogspot.com/

item.title: Wind To Power Water
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded: With an electric bill above $20 million each year, Maui County is looking to cut its power costs anywhere it can -- even in remote locations to pump water. The Maui News has the story today: http://bit.ly/ojZh4P

item.title: Deep Ocean Air Conditioning
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Somebody finally is going to take advantage of the ocean around Oahu to cut on-shore energy costs. It's not ocean thermal energy conversion that's moving ahead; it's sea-water air conditioning. The company that has designed a system to service high-rise buildings in downtown Honolulu has signed a lease for land makai of the "Gold Bond Building" to build a water-circulation plant. (Consider yourself a kama`aina if you know where that is.)

The Star-Advertiser has the story: http://bit.ly/qwoJfF

Now, about OTEC.... See recent posts in the Renewables section.

item.title: "Mad as Hell" Wind Power Firm Sues
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded: The potential impact of industrial-scale wind turbines is becoming an issue far beyond Hawaii. The Ontario province's government in Canada has been sued by a wind power provider for damages it says it incurred when the government placed a moratorium on off-shore wind projects. Here's the story: http://bit.ly/q2XSMk

item.title: Big Isle Geothermal Plans on Review
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Want an excellent example of how times have changed? Then consider how attitudes have done a "180" on geothermal development on the island of Hawaii.

West Hawaii Today had a story this week < http://bit.ly/nUGup7 > about the intentions of Innovations Development Group (IDG) to tap into the island's subsurface heat and create electricity for use on Hawaii and perhaps on other islands. IDG and other companies have responded to a request for information from Hawaii Electric Light Company on their capabilities to create additional geothermal power.

Waimea's meeting was last night; Kona's meeting is tonight (9/29) from 6 to 9:30 at Kealakehe High School.

item.title: Status Update on Kauai Water Energy Projects
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
GardenIsland.com reported yesterday < http://bit.ly/oDyYqg > on the status of Free Flow Power's intentions to build more than 20 MW of hydro-power facilities in Kauai waterways. No meeting dates are yet set.

The company has been conducting outreach to community groups to hear their concerns, if any, about these projects. What if any are your concerns? Let us know here at the Forum by following the links in the upper-right corner to register. Mahalo.

item.title: PUC Rejects Proposed Biofuel Contract
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
The Public Utilities Commission has shot down a Hawaiian Electric Company proposal to buy biofuel from a new Big Island enterprise, burn it to create electricity for Big Island customers and spread the above-oil price for the fuel to Big Island and Oahu customers. Big Island Video News' report covers the details of the decision: http://bit.ly/nZNSEi

Although the rate Aina Koa Pono would have charged the utility remains confidential, the PUC said the premium that would have been paid for the fuel over a 20-year contract would have been "nine figures" -- at least $100,000,000 -- above the anticipated future price of oil to generate electricity.

The PUC's decision said in part: "...the commission finds and concludes that the contract price for the AKP-produced biofuel is excessive, not cost-effective, and thus, is unreasonable and inconsistent with the public interest."

We're speculating here, but perhaps the commission's finding of "unreasonable" costs that aren't consistent with the public interest will apply to other renewable energy projects still on the drawing boards. Lanai and Molokai residents who object to the Big Wind project and the splitting of 400 megawatts of wind power production plants between the islands might find reason to take heart from this biofuel decision.

item.title: Kauai Council Rejects Bid To Require Solar Heating
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Hawaii's state energy policy is to end the islands' dependence on fossil fuels and do it asap. That's why some are seeking an end to the variance in state law that allows gas water heating to be installed in new homes as an option to solar water heating. The law requires one or the other in new home construction.

A committee of the Kauai County Council has voted against a proposal that would end the gas option. GardenIsland.com has the story: http://bit.ly/qz8d6Y

What do you think? Should the gas option remain on the books, or is the importance of getting off oil and all fossil fuels wherever feasible important enough to strike the variance from the books? Sign up and start contributing your views here at The Forum.

item.title: A&B's Solar Plant Up for Kauai Discussion
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Alexander & Baldwin is moving its planned solar power facility to the next round of discussions -- before the Kauai County Planning Commission. The local newspaper there had a story yesterday on the project's status: http://bit.ly/nggTF8 A recent public meeting had a low public turnout.

The Public Utilities Commission has the A&B-KIUC contract before it with its proposed 20 cent/kilowatthour sale price to the utility over 20 years. If approved at all levels, the project would begin construction late this year and be completed before the end of next.

Any thoughts, Kauai citizens? You pay among the highest prices for electricity in the country. What say you about the addition of 20,000 to 30,000 solar panels on your land? Is this a good deal for the Garden Island? Let us know your thoughts here at The Forum.

item.title: The Consumer's Stake in Clean Energy Initiatives
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
The Public Utilities Commission's recent rejection of the Aina Koa Pono contact to provide biofuel to Hawaii Electric Light Company over as 20-year period involves corporate-size issues, but it also focuses attention on an important fact that consumers should remember:

Residential and commercial electricity customers pay for clean energy initiatives through their power bills. Massive energy projects receive their short-term financing from banks and other institutions, but in the long term, you and I pay for the presumed benefit of reducing Hawaii's dependence on imported fuel.

Some think that's worth doing no matter the cost. Aina Koa Pono is suggesting that approach between the lines, but the PUC apparently sees it differently and rejected the contract that it said could produce a nine-figure premium over the cost of traditional fuels during the contract period.

Renewable energy is a pocketbook issue for Hawaii consumers. What's your take on the cost to get off oil? Should we embrace higher electric bills for the presumed benefit of increasing our energy independence, reducing greenhouse gases, etc., or are our dollars too precious to pay for "nice to have" rather than "need to have" energy projects?

This is YOUR forum, so start writing; register at the link in the top-right corner.

Civil Beat background story: http://bit.ly/nWVyil

item.title: Geothermal Update
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Geothermal energy is heating up. Sorry--couldn't resist that one -- but it's true that a strong push is evident by both the utilities and private companies to expand geothermal's contributions to the state's energy supply.

The Star-Advertiser carried an update story a few days ago < http://bit.ly/nJsuGi >, and the paper editorialized yesterday on it: http://bit.ly/pqjsOH . On Saturday October 15th, representatives from Hawaiian Electric Company, Puna Geothermal Ventures, Innovations Development Group and Ku`oko`a will give presentations on geothermal development potential around Hawaii. The session will be held at Bellows Air Force Station, 8 am to 12:30 pm. Here are the details: http://bit.ly/qXaJiK

As we noted in another Topic post a few minutes ago, any additional geothermal energy contributions to the islands' electricity grid will be paid for by you, the consumer. Even at this late date, there probably are people here who believe wind power and other renewables can be added to the grid and reduce costs. That might be true for some proposals, but as the PUC's recent rejection of a biofuels contract signaled, alternate fuels can be expensive.

What's your take -- pay more happily because it's "green power," or pay more reluctantly?

item.title: HECO Rates Hit All-Time High
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Remember those infamous "outage pockets" after hurricanes Iwa and Iniki? If you were in one, you had to wait longer than other neighborhoods to have your power restored.

Guess what. The entire state is in a "cost pocket' regarding the cost of electricity. Oil prices are falling nearly everywhere else, but not Hawaii. Pacific Business News < http://bit.ly/pas54K > and the Star-Advertiser < http://bit.ly/nxlpwN > report today that electricity prices on Oahu in October have broken through to a new record -- even as the price of oil is dipping everywhere but here. The reason, says HECO, is that the low-sulfur crude oil burned in HECO's power plants is in high demand. Japan's distress over nuclear power following the March 11th earthquake and tsunami is adding to that higher demand.

And that means higher costs for the oil refined here by Tesoro and Chevron and higher costs for the residual fuel oil that's burned in the plants.

Doesn't that just burn you up, too? Sign up here at the Forum and start writing.

item.title: It Takes a "Forum" To Keep Energy Issues Straight
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
The Hawaii Energy Forum -- this site that you've maybe found by following a link from Twitter or Facebook -- exists as a place where you and other electricity customers can discuss and debate energy issues. Not much discussing and debating has been going on here at the Forum since its launch early this year. We've been thinking through some ways to remodel this site as a valuable tool for ratepayers to understand their energy options, including how to save money. We've not publicized the site in the media, but that's about to change.

And the timing will be right for rolling out the Forum to a wider audience. Electricity costs are the highest on record on Oahu this month and presumably also on the neighbor islands. The principal reason for the nation's highest power costs is Hawaii's dependence on oil to generate electricity -- accounting for approximately 77 percent of the state's electrical generation. That's not a sustainable practice, and the state has widely publicized goals to reduce that dependence sharply by 2030.

Getting Off Oil (the GOO project) is the name of the game, and utilities seemingly have a menu of options and initiatives they're trying. Hawaiian Electric Company is asking for proposals to supply Oahu with 200 megawatts of renewable energy by the end of 2018. Civil Beat has the story, which should be readable even by casual visitors to its subscription site: http://bit.ly/oZKT1g The story has links to other renewable projects that are in various stages of fits-and-starts development.

HECO also has made news recently about using biofuel in its Kahe power plant, also covered by Civil Beat: http://bit.ly/nOhshX Then there's the PUC's rejection of a biofuel contract between Aina Koa Pono and Hawaii Electric Light Company that we wrote about here at the Forum in late September (find it in the Renewables category). Today's Honolulu Star-Advertiser's editorial supports renewable energy development -- something the paper and others have been advocating for decades: http://bit.ly/raqCSA (You probably need to be a subscriber to read it.)

Other renewable energy projects include the Big Wind project on Molokai and Lanai that seems like a jungle of tangled story lines by now. Kauai is going strong on solar power, a "utility scale" solar farm is moving ahead on Oahu -- the list goes on, and keeping it all straight might require a matrix that shows which renewable technologies are intended for which islands.

Short of creating your own matrix, the Hawaii Energy Forum is here to help. We follow these developments at the Forum, but more importantly, this is where you can jump into the discussion and express your own views, fears, concerns, hopes -- whatever you're feeling -- about Hawaii's energy issues and challenges. Ask questions about reducing home electricity consumption. Extoll the virtues of your new all-electric car. Whatever it is, you're encouraged to write about it as long as it contributes the the discussion of energy issues in the Aloha State.

Sign-up is free; just follow the links after clicking in the upper-right corner. We can't wait to hear from you.

item.title: News Roundup: Geothermal, Big Wind, Administrator
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
It was a typical weekend news-wise in the energy sector. A gathering at Bellows Air Station focused on geothermal energy as a potential source of power for the island chain using an undersea cable. Representatives from Hawaiian Electric Company, government, private industry (including Ku`oko`a, the company that seeks to buy HECO's parent, Hawaiian Electric Industries), native Hawaiians -- it was a come-together kind of meeting that reflected major attitudinal shifts over the past two decades. Civil Beat's story has the details: http://bit.ly/pmtSnI

Other news at the start of the week includes the appointment of Mark Glick as the State's new Energy Administrator. He fills the spot once occupied by Ted Peck, now Ku`oko`a's president. PBN's story: http://bit.ly/pFJEaN

item.title: What Price Renewable Energy?
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Today's ThinkTech column in the Star-Advertiser < http://bit.ly/uLGAk1 > (subscription required) raises a number of issues not actually found in the column. Author Jay Fidell argues that the PUC's recent rejection of the Aina Koa Pono's proposed contract to supply biofuel to Big Island power plants was a major setback for renewables in Hawaii.

Strictly writing as an individual and not for The Forum, we're not so sure. The PUC believes some renewable costs aren't worth the expense to consumers -- or so its recent decision would seem.

It's a legitimate debate -- get off oil at all costs due to Hawaii's dangerous dependence on imported petroleum, or set reasonable limits and set sail for other green energy goals and projects.

What do YOU think? We wrote about these issues at the Hawaii Energy Options blog today: http://bit.ly/vowi7I Have a look and tell us here at The Forum your views.

item.title: Solar Tax Credits in the Balance?
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Civil Beat had the story earlier this week -- and it's sending chills through the local solar industry and its supporters who believe solar photovoltaic power is a heaven-made option to reduce Hawaii's dependence on fossil fuel.

The story < http://bit.ly/uKfubH > reports on concerns by some that the state tax credits, which add up to tens of millions of dollars in revenue not collected, are being abused. Solar industry representatives deny that it's happening -- or if it is, the abuse is minimal and doesn't justify jeopardizing the industry.

What's your view on this brewing tempest? Have you installed solar, and what was your experience? If you're saving money, how much? Are there ways to improve Hawaii's solar program?

The Forum wants to know, so register above and start writing.

item.title: I Aloha Molokai Group Digs In
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
Molokai residents over the years have opposed projects they believe would be injurious to their island. Their "media" have included small signs nailed to fences and posts throughout the Friendly Isle.

Opponents of the Big Wind industrial-scane energy project, which would put scores of turbines on the island, have stepped up their media campaign more than a notch. Their media effort includes professional-quality video segments produced and edited by a documentarian who lives on Molokai, PF Bentley. He posted a short commentary and one of his videos at Civil Beat today: http://bit.ly/tXkPiy

What's your take on Big Wind? Do you agree with the I Aloha Molokai group that Big Wind's impacts would be too much to bear, or do you side with those who believe Hawaii's oil dependence demands projects like Big Wind no matter the cost? Sign up above and start writing.

item.title: Recent Big Wind Developments
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
We're catching up on the ongoing soap opera on Molokai about the Big Wind energy project. By "soap opera," we're referring to the project's dramatic twists and turns, including players dropping in and out and the Governor's ongoing insistence that Molokai and Lanai should carry the burden of providing power to Oahu.

Molokai residents aren't having any of it, as our blog (independent of The Forum) has summarized today: http://bit.ly/vBeqsg

What about alternatives to Big Wind? It on average would send less than 200 megawatts of electrical energy to Oahu due to the intermittency of wind power. Do you think Big Wind deserves its shot, or should it be shelved in favor of other options -- OTEC and geothermal energy, for example?

Sign up and start writing.

item.title: Lanai Energy Leadership
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
It's too soon to write off the proposed Big Wind energy development on Lanai an Molokai, but judging from how the islands' residents are reacting to it, Big Wind's prospects appear to be waning.

A new Topic was posted on October 30 in the News category here at The Forum. (Click on FORUMS, upper-left, then on News in the list of catregories.) The title is THE WIND POWER SOLUTION PERSPECTIVE. You are urged to read the post by "Cyber" and react to it -- but to do so here in this Lanai Energy Leadership topic within the Renewables category.

Cyber calls for leadership within the Lanai community on finding appropriate options for the island's energy future, and we have suggested beneath Cyber's comment that ocean thermal energy conversion's potential to make Lanai a world leader in this technology's development might well deserve a second look. The first look didn't go anywhere.

Let's keep this discussion alive here at The Forum.

item.title: Who Controls Molokai's Future?
item.dc:creator: Doug Carlson
item.content:encoded:
The Big Wind controversy will continue and only get hotter if the views of ThinkTech columnist Jay Fidell hold sway. His column on 11/6 headlined "Molokai cannot be allowed to isolate itself from Oahu" is sure to fire up the opposition to the 200-MW (or bigger) wind energy project that the state's energy powerhouse community seems desperate to implement.

Your host here has posted on this latest round of the Big Wind controversy at his energy blog: http://bit.ly/rBcy0W Tell us what you think by registering and writing here at Hawaii Energy's Forum.
